page.title: 19WILDLIFE OF THE REGION
page.content: The most complete record for the region came from Elvaston Castle. Mr. Nick Brown, development officer and Mrs. Pat Brassley, conservation officer for Derbyshire Naturalists Trust, both based Elvaston Castle provided the following information. Brindstone Butterflies are increasing and have done so for the past three to four years. Elvaston is the place where they are most commonly seen in the county with nineteen being seen in a group last year. The Gatekeeper Butterfly is now established at Elvaston and the Comma butterfly is increasing. The first confirmed breeding in the county is of a Broad-bodied Chaser, (LIBELLULA DEPRESSA) a dragon-fly came from Elvaston in July in 1984. A good range of woodland birds are to be found. No unusual plants seen.
